en.title: How you can proceed with your divorce
en.courtHearsBothParties: The court usually needs to hear from both parties in a marriage before it can grant a divorce.
en.infoToContactRespondent: If it's safe to do so, usually the simplest way to proceed is to contact your {{ case.divorceWho }} directly to find out why they haven't responded. They can still send in their response after the deadline has passed.
en.provideNewAddrToCourt: If you can't get in contact with your {{ case.divorceWho }}, you may want to consider asking their family, friends and workplace if they have a new address, and provide that to the court.
en.noResponseOptions: If there's still no response using the original address, you have the following options available to you, depending on your situation.

haveAnotherAddress.linkSummary: I have another residential address or a solicitor's address for my {{ case.divorceWho }} (no fee)
haveAnotherAddress.provideAddress: Contact the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre to provide a different address for your {{ case.divorceWho }}. This can be a UK or international address.
haveAnotherAddress.noExtraPay: You don't have to pay anything extra to have the application sent to a different address.

sendToWorkAddress.linkSummary: I need to send the application to a non-residential address, eg a work address (£{{ feeToResendApplication }})
sendToWorkAddress.askToSendApp: You can ask for the application to be sent to a non-residential address.

needToSearchRecords.linkSummary: I need to search government records for my {{ case.divorceWho }}’s address (£{{ feeToResendApplication }})
needToSearchRecords.canApplyIfRespLivesInEngWales: You can apply for a search of government databases (eg the electoral role) for your {{ case.divorceWho }}’s address. Your {{ case.divorceWho }} must live in England or Wales.
needToSearchRecords.applyViaSearchRecords: Contact the service centre and ask for the form to be sent to you.

sendEmailToResp.linkSummary: I need to send the application to my {{ case.divorceWho }}'s email address (£{{ feeToResendApplication }})
sendEmailToResp.appToEmail: You can ask for the application to be delivered by email.

believeRespChoseNotToRespond.linkSummary: I believe my {{ case.divorceWho }} lives at that address, but chose not to respond (£{{ enforcemetFee }})
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.deliverPapersDirectlyToResp: If you think that your {{ case.divorceWho }} is deliberately not responding you can pay a professional to deliver (serve) the divorce papers directly to them.
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.optionsToDeliver: You can do this by using either a:
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.courtEmpToDeliver: Court bailiff (an employee of the courts)
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.processServerDetails: Contact a local solicitor who should be able to give you the contact details for a local company.
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.courtBailifDetails1: The bailiff service can only be used at addresses in England and Wales where delivery by post has already failed. If you have a new address for your {{ case.divorceWho }}, you’ll have to get it delivered by post before you can apply for the bailiff service.
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.courtBailifDetails2: If the bailiff succeeds in delivering the application, you'll be given a letter as evidence that your {{ case.divorceWho }} has received the application. This is known as an ‘endorsement of service'. If your {{ case.divorceWho }} doesn’t respond within 14 days of getting the application, you can use this letter to continue your divorce without their response.
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.formD89: form D89. Send the form to the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre.
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.moreToSend: You'll also need to send the following:
believeRespChoseNotToRespond.divorceAppCopy: a copy of your divorce application

evidenceRespWontRespond.linkSummary: I have evidence that my {{ case.divorceWho }} received the application, but can't or won't respond (£{{ feeToResendApplication }})
evidenceRespWontRespond.canApplyForDeemedServ: If you know your {{ case.divorceWho }} received the application, but can’t or won’t respond, you can apply to the court for a ‘deemed service’. This means that the court will decide that your {{ case.divorceWho }} has received the application, and that you can continue without their response.
evidenceRespWontRespond.needToProve: You need to be able to prove that your {{ case.divorceWho }} received the application (eg, you have a text message from {{ case.divorceWho }} saying they received it).
evidenceRespWontRespond.applyAndSendDocs: Send the form and documents to the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre.

doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.linkSummary: I’ve tried every possible way of delivering the application (£{{feeToResendApplication }})
doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.askForDispenseWithService: Under exceptional circumstances, you can ask the court to ‘dispense with service’ (decide your {{ case.divorceWho }} doesn’t have to be served the divorce application).
doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.allInCourtHands: It’s up to the court to decide whether to grant this. Before it can be considered, you’ll need to show that you’ve done everything you can to find them by contacting their:
doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.searchInGovtDB: You'll also need to have tried to find their address by searching for it on government databases.
doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.applyD13bLink: form D13b.
doneWithAllWaysOfDelivering.applyD11AndD13bContent: Send the forms to the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre.

en.applyD11: form D11.
en.howToPayContent: Call the service centre to make the £{{ feeToResendApplication }} payment by card (Monday - Friday 8am to 8pm, Saturday 8am to 2pm) or include a cheque with your form.
en.howToPayBailiffContent: Call the service centre to make the £{{ enforcemetFee }} payment by card (Monday - Friday 8am to 8pm, Saturday 8am to 2pm) or include a cheque with your form.
en.getNewRefNumb: If you're eligible for help with fees you'll need to apply again and get a new reference number.
en.extraCosts: If you asked the court to order your {{ case.divorceWho }} to pay your costs, then these extra costs will also be taken into account.
en.printAndSend: Send the form to the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre.
en.howRespondsLink: How your {{ case.divorceWho }} responds
en.decreeNisiLink: Decree nisi
en.decreeAbsoluteLink: Decree absolute
en.childrenAndDivorceLink: Children and divorce
en.moneyAndPropertyLink: Money and property
en.solicitorLink: solicitor or legal adviser
